numbered_ace_sentences: 1. A legacy applicant is an applicant who has a relative who attended the university.
2. A legacy applicant is 7 times as likely to be admitted as a non-legacy applicant.
3. A non-legacy applicant is an applicant who has no relative who attended the university.
4. Some elite universities are Ivy League universities.
5. If an applicant has legacy status, then the applicant has a higher chance of admission than a non-legacy applicant.
6. An applicant has parents.
7. Some parents have a high income rank.
8. If the income rank of an applicant's parents is higher, then the chance of admission of the applicant is higher.
9. Some applicants are upper-class applicants.
10. If an applicant is more upper-class, then the chance of admission of the applicant is higher.
11. Some applicants have the same test scores.
12. Even if two applicants have the same test scores, the legacy applicant has a higher chance of admission than the non-legacy applicant.
13. I wonder why a non-legacy applicant has a lower chance of admission than a legacy applicant when both applicants have the same test scores.
14. Some families have many generations.
15. Some generations of a family wish to attend the same prestigious school.
16. I think that this situation is not fair to other applicants.
17. Some applicants work as hard as other applicants.
18. Some applicants are first-generation applicants.
19. A first-generation applicant is an applicant whose family has no history of attending the university.
20. I think that elite colleges wish to keep their students elite.
21. I think that this wish relates to the higher admission chance of legacy applicants.
22. I think that many legacy applicants come from wealthy families.
23. Some wealthy families have connections.
24. Some wealthy families use connections to their advantage.
25. Some wealthy families use legacy history to their advantage.
